title: feat: update rust edition and some deps
body:
## Overview

- Update rust edition to 2021
- Update a few dependencies that Dependabot is warning about

title: feat: show run url when finished
body:
## Overview

- Shows a URL to the run if the webhook return a `url` property

## Details

To make it easier for the user to debug errors when using capter.io or their own webhook, the CLI will now display the `url` property if it's returned from the webhook:

```sh
---

Posting result... ✓
done! ✨

---

Inspect run: http://capter.io/xyz
```

title: test: improve test coverage
body:
## Overview

- Add more test

title: feat: add init command
body:
## Overview

- Add `init` command

## Details

The `init` creates an example workflow to make it super easy for users to start using Capter. The onboarding flow can now be:

```sh
$ npm i capter --save-dev
$ npx capter init
$ npx capter test --token [TOKEN]
```

## Checklist

- [ ] I have added tests for new features
- [ ] I have updated the documentation

title: feat: add error body
body:
## Overview

- Add errors response body if it exists.

## Details

This PR makes sure the body of the response is added to the payload, even if we're getting an error.

## Checklist

- [x] I have added tests for new features

title: feat: dotenv
body:
## Overview

- Read `.env` file
- Update the npm package to reflect that the repo is now public

## Details

Adding support for `.env` files makes it a lot easier to handle environment variables. The CLI will now read the .env using the [`dotenv` crate](https://crates.io/crates/dotenv).

## Checklist

- [x] I have updated the documentation

title: feat: use github event file
body:
## Overview

- Use a generic CI payload
- Get all GitHub Actions information from event.json

title: feat: read github actions event file
body:
## Overview

- Reads the `event.json` file provided by GitHub actions

## Details

To be able to support pull requests comments we need to get some extra information from GitHub Actions. Currently we collect the `sha`, and when an action is triggered by the `pull_request` event, that sha is not the actual one used by head, so there won't be any PR connected to it.

By reading the `event.json` file provided by GitHub Actions we can get the PR number, which is the one we need. We can also get the PR title which will be a nice addition to the web app.

title: feat: add extra info from github actions
body:
## Overview

- Add better support for GitHub actions

## Details

By default we grab git information from the git project, but that doesn't always work on GitHub actions (on some events like `pull_request`). This PR reads info from the GitHub Actions environment variables.

title: feat: add support for generic headers in workflow
body:
## Overview

- Add generic headers to workflows

## Details

Sometimes you want to pass headers to every request. For example "content-type" or "authorization". This PR add support for adding that:

```yml
name: headers
headers:
  authorization: Bearer ${{ env.token }}
steps:
  - name: step 1
    headers:
       foo: bar
```

This will merge the workflow headers with the step headers:

```yml
headers:
  authorization: Bearer ${{ env.token }}
  foo: bar
```

## Checklist

- [x] I have added tests for new features
- [x] I have updated the documentation

title: feat: add logger
body:
## Overview

- Log to a file whenever a workflow fails

## Details

It needs to be easy to figure out why a workflow is failing when using capter locally during development. This PR adds a logger that will log the request and response of failed workflows.

They end up in `.capter/logs`, and there will be one file for each failed workflow.

## Checklist

- [ ] I have added tests for new features
- [x] I have updated the documentation

title: feat: timeout and user agent
body:
## Overview

- Set the user agent to capter
- Add timeout option to CLI

## Details

#### Set the user agent to capter

To make sure people know where the requests are coming for we want to to be transparent that Capter is the one making the requests.

#### Add timeout option to CLI

When running the tests in CI you sometimes want to fail fast. With the `timeout` argument you can now set it to something like 5 sec, and the request will fail if it takes longer than that.

## Checklist

- [x] I have updated the documentation

title: feat: add support for method in url
body:
## Overview

- Support for adding the method directly in the URL

## Details

To make the configuration smaller, it makes sense to put the method directly in the URL. This also makes it easier to read.

```yml
# old
url: https://fake-api.capter/api/posts
method: POST

# new
url: POST https://fake-api.capter/api/posts
```

## Checklist

Remove options that are not relevant.

- [x] I have added tests for new features
- [x] I have updated the documentation

title: feat: rename assert to expect
body:
## Overview

- Renamed the `!assert` YAML tag to `!expect`

## Details

Since we are going for *plain English* assertions, it looks a lot better with `expect` than `assert`.

```yaml
# old
assertions:
  - !assert body.id to_equal 5

# new
assertions:
  - !expect body.id to_equal 5
```

## Checklist

Remove options that are not relevant.

- [ ] I have updated the documentation

title: build: add npm
body:
### What this PR is about:

- Add NPM support

### Add NPM support

Even though this is a Rust CLI, we want to support as many package managers as possible. NPM is the major one for Node.js, so it makes sense to add it.

 We use our own modified version of [binary-install](https://github.com/EverlastingBugstopper/binary-install) that supports private repos. Once we're public, we can probably change back to use that package.

#### How it works

The package doesn't actually include the CLI, since it's different depending on the users OS. The package will check the current OS and download the binary for it. 

#### How to use it

```sh
# npm
npm i @capterqa/cli --save-dev

# yarn
yarn add @capterqa/cli --dev
```

And then:

```sh
npm run capter test
yarn capter test
npx capter test
```

title: feat: add exit codes
body:
### What this PR is about:

- Adds exit codes so instead of panicing on errors, we now display a real error message and the exit code.
- If any test fails, we now exit with code 1, which will make it error in CI etc. If success, we exit with 1.

feat: replace handlebars with own logic
body:
### What this PR is about: 

- Replace `handlebars` with a custom function.
- Add full test coverage to the compile functions.

#### Motivation

- `handlebars` comes with a lot of features we don't use and produces overhead in both compile size and compile time.
- In the future we will need to do a better job of returning the correct type of values, and that is not possible with handlebars as it always returns a string. Currently if you do `my_value: "5"`, it will be returned as `my_value: 5` (there's logic guessing the type based on the value). This is fixable now, but not when using handlebars.

title: feat: make bundle smaller
body:
### What this PR is about:

Makes the built binary smaller by:

- Removing large dependencies (replaced reqwest and tokio with ureq)
- Adding a release profile

#### Diff in Cargo.lock file:

```diff
+ 77 additions
- 682 deletions
```

### Result

```
Previous build: 7.2MB (3.4MB with strip)
New build: 5.2MB (3MB with strip)
```

Compile time is down with about 30-35%.

title: ci: add @actions-rs/toolchain workflow
body:
### What this PR is about:

Adds a GitHub action that:

- Builds and runs the CLI
- Tests the code
- Gathers test coverage and submits it to codecov
- Uses `semantic-release` to check for a new version (this will be used for publish in the future)
